explanation:
To determine compliance with the MISRA rule about well-formed for loops we must examine any for loops in the target function itself and in any functions called (the rule counts the behaviour of called functions). The following symbols are therefore required (bodies/implementations or authoritative headers):

- exit
  - OS_ApplicationExit directly calls exit. To be sure no non-compliant for loops exist in the library implementation invoked here, the implementation (or a verified library contract) must be inspected.

- EXIT_SUCCESS, EXIT_FAILURE
  - Macros/constants used as arguments to exit; include for completeness to understand any macro expansion or side-effects (rare but necessary to rule out hidden behaviour).

- UT_Stub_RegisterContextWithMetaData
  - Appears as a callee of OS_ApplicationExit in the static call graph (unit-test instrumentation may redirect exit through this). Its implementation must be checked for any for loops that could violate the rule.

- UT_ExecuteBasicHandler
  - Also listed as a callee of OS_ApplicationExit by the test harness. Its body may call further functions and contain for loops; its source is needed.

- UT_GetStubEntry
  - Callee of both UT_Stub_RegisterContextWithMetaData and UT_ExecuteBasicHandler. Its implementation could contain for loops or perform modifications relevant to loop-counter rules.

- UtAssert_Abort
  - Callee of UT_Stub_RegisterContextWithMetaData. Must be checked for any for loops or side effects impacting loop analysis.

- UT_SetHandlerFunction
  - Callee of UT_ExecuteBasicHandler. Include to inspect any loops inside it or side-effects called from there.

- UT_DefaultStubImpl
  - Callee of UT_ExecuteBasicHandler. Its implementation must be inspected for for-loops and whether they conform to the MISRA rule.

- OS_SUCCESS
  - The constant compared to Status. Include to ensure no macro/side-effect hidden in its definition and to understand branch selection (mainly for completeness).

- int32
  - Typedef of the Status parameter. Include to confirm it is an ordinary integer type (MISRA concerns about integer types used as loop counters and modifications are relevant when analyzing loop constructs in called code).

In short: obtain the source/definitions for the above symbols (or an authoritative contract showing they contain no non-conforming for loops) so that any for-loops executed as part of OS_ApplicationExit (including those inside called functions) can be analyzed against the MISRA well-formed for-loop rule.
